section.name: JWebUnit Quickstart
section.p: This quickstart contains sample code and guidance to get you started with JWebUnit. To see all of the methods available, consult the Javadocs - particularly the WebTestCase class for full documentation.

Configuring Logback
subsection.p: Apache Commons' HTTP Components project, one of the dependencies of JWebUnit, uses the logback logging framework extensively. This means that if you do not have logback correctly configured, you will get a lot of debug information piped to stdout.

A simple way to configure logback is to create a file called logback.xml with the following contents, and placing it in your source folder (for example, src). This will suppress all debugging messages unless they are at the ERROR level or higher.
subsection.source:
<configuration debug="false"> <!-- definition of appender STDOUT --> <appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender"> <encoder> <pattern>%-4relative [%thread] %-5level %logger{35} - %msg %n</pattern> </encoder> </appender>
<root level="ERROR"> <!-- appender referenced after it is defined --> <appender-ref ref="STDOUT"/> </root> </configuration>

Navigating Your Web Application
subsection.p: Note that you should not be pointing to the production version of your web application, but rather a sandboxed development or testing server!

subsection.name: Working With Forms
subsection.p: JWebUnit, through HtmlUnit/Selenium, automatically keeps track of cookies and session variables specified by the web application, allowing you to traverse through your site as if you were a normal user.

subsection.name: Validating Page Content
subsection.p: Once you have navigated to the page you wish to test, you can call the assertions provided by JWebUnit to verify it's correctness.

subsection.name: Validating Table Content
subsection.p: A number of assertions are provided by JWebUnit to validate the contents of tables on a page. You can simply check for the presence of text within a table, or check layout of all or a portion of the table. HttpUnit is used to purge empty rows and columns from the actual table before comparison, so you may leave spacer cells and rows out of your check.

subsection.name: Using Element IDs to Validate Content
subsection.p: JWebUnit allows you to check for the presence of any html element by its id, or for text in an element. This can be a useful trick to check for the presence of some logical part of the page. Even in the case of free floating text, a span element can be used to surround the text and give it a logical id:
Welcome, Joe User!

subsection.name: Using Property Files to Validate Content
subsection.p: Whether to check for a given logical chunk of text by hard-coded string, property file lookup, or by use of an element id is up to you.
For more information, consult the Javadocs.
